Description: Fragment of painted mud-plaster in the form of a cavetto cornice, originally part of the architectural decoration of a mudbrick house, perhaps over and around a doorway. The cornice itself is formed from vertical bands of blue, green and red, divided by white areas. Immediately beneath is a torus moulding, with red bands indicating the binding. The area beneath features a flower-petal motif (in blue), abovea band of alternate red and yellow squares. At the base of the preserved fragment, rectangles of red, blue and green are outlined in black ink, part of a larger design.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Amarna, el-, Object 26/7 'NE group, house A' (inked note on reverse of object)
Curator's comments: It is likely that this is the fragment described in Frankfort and Pendlebury, City of Akhenaten II (London, 1933), 5. The authors describe the discovery of fragments around the entrance to house V.37.1, at the top of the flight of steps. Published: T.G.H. James. Egyptian Painting (1985). 38 fig. 40. M. Stead. Egyptian Life (1994). fig. 12.
